column5: Motorola Reports Profit On Smartphone Sales, Cost Cuts
column8: Motorola swung to a fourth-quarter profit as the embattled handset maker showed some signs of life, thanks to the holiday launch of the Droid smartphone.

column5: Kodak, Reversing Loss, Sees 'Momentum Returning'
column8: The photo and imaging company swung to a $443 million profit, thanks to cost cuts, growth in digital products and improved profit margins.

column5: Apple's iPad Changes the Landscape for App Makers
column8: Apple's iPad has the potential to be both a blessing and a curse to the growing ranks of companies that have developed more than 140,000 iPhone applications.

column5: Apple-Designed Chip Marks Strategy Shift
column8: Apple's new iPad uses an internally designed microprocessor, the first fruits of a strategy shift for a company that has long used external semiconductor suppliers.

column5: For Wireless Carriers, iPad Signals Further Loss of Clout
column8: AT&T won the right to carry Apple's iPad in the U.S., a coup for the company but on terms that further erode the wireless industry's carrier-centered model.

column5: For Media Industry, a Mixed Bag in iPad
column8: Apple's iPad aims to upend how people read and pay for books but there are few signs that it presents a new model for distributing TV shows, movies and magazines.

column5: Giving Mobile Ads a Makeover
column8: Google, Apple and several start-ups are trying to break the mold in mobile advertising, hoping to persuade marketers to spend more on a format the tech industry has been hyping for years, with little to show for it.

column5: New Device Revives Gadget Debate
column8: Apple's iPad reviews a classic gadget debate: Do consumers want devices that do one thing well, or all-in-one wonders that accomplish many tasks?

column5: Early Look: iPad Has Familiar Feel to an iPhone User
column8: With its introduction of iPhone's big brother, Apple may have redefined the laptop.

column5: Amazon's Profit Soars 71%
column8: Amazon said sales jumped 42% during the holiday quarter, and the Internet retailer forecast continued gains this quarter.

column5: Nokia Recharged, Motorola Trails
column8: Nokia posted a 65% jump in quarterly profit and regained market share, while rival Motorola reversed a year-ago loss but continued to lag the competition.

column5: Movie Gallery Plans Restructuring
column8: Hollywood Video owner Movie Gallery is preparing a restructuring plan that involves closing as many as two-thirds of its video-rental outlets.

column5: Holiday PC Sales Boost Microsoft
column8: Microsoft's quarterly profit jumped 60% as the software giant benefited from strong sales of computers running its new Windows 7.

column5: Meet the iPad
column8: Apple Inc. CEO Steve Jobs on Wednesday unveiled the iPad, a tablet-style computer that resembles the iPhone, but larger.

column5: Meet the iPad
column8: Steve Jobs said the bar for a third category of device, something between a smart phone and a laptop, is high.

column5: Tabula Rasa: Apple's Press Release, Before the Editing
column8: Talk about excitement. Is this the tablet from California or the one from Sinai? Reply to All offers a rare glimpse behind the Cupertino curtain.

column5: Borders Group CEO Ron Marshall Resigns
column8: Ron Marshall resigned as president and chief executive of Borders Group to take the reins of supermarket chain A&P.

column5: Foxconn Shares Drop on Profit Warning
column8: The contract mobile phone manufacturer said it expects a "significant decline" in 2009 profit because the global economic downturn hit demand and prices.

column5: Apple Tablet Portends Rewrite for Publishers
column8: Book publishers were locked in 11th-hour negotiations with Apple that aim to rewrite the industry's revenue model after the technology giant unveils its highly anticipated tablet device.

column5: Apple Seeks to Avoid Past Tablet Flops
column8: As Apple prepares to unveil its tablet, the biggest question is whether changes since the early 1990s in the technology landscapeï¿½ï¿½and consumer habitsï¿½ï¿½could give it a different ending than previous tablet forays.

column5: LG Display Swings to Loss
column8: LG Display reported it swung to a fourth-quarter net loss due to falling panel prices and a hefty fine imposed by the European Commission for price fixing in the liquid crystal display market.

column5: Power Shifts Atop Google
column8: Google surprised the technology world by naming co-founder Larry Page to replace longtime Chief Executive Eric Schmidt, the biggest management shake-up since the Internet search giant was an obscure California start-up.

column5: Sony Ericsson Posts Profit But Sales Sink
column8: Mobile-phone maker Sony Ericsson eked out a small fourth-quarter profit, as the company cut prices to woo customers.

column5: Samsung Electronics Buys Display Maker
column8: Samsung Electronics said Thursday it acquired Dutch display technology firm Liquavista for an undisclosed sum last month in the latest move by the Korean technology giant to expand into next-generation displays.

column5: Apple, JPMorgan Chase: Money Flow Leaders (AAPL, JPM)
column8: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

column5: Remember Google? Earnings Will Ring Bell
column8: Apple and Facebook have been grabbing all the attention, but Google could muscle its way back into the technology spotlight with its fourth-quarter earnings.

column5: Nokia Cancels U.S. Launch of X7 Phone
column8: Nokia has canceled the U.S. release of a smartphone that was slated to launch exclusively this year with AT&T, the latest setback in the U.S. for the cellphone giant.

column5: Apple, Procter & Gamble: Money Flow Leaders (AAPL, PG)
column8: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

column5: Business Spending Bolsters Tech Earnings
column8: IBM, Apple and Intel each reported record quarterly results, pushed by corporations pouring more cash into technology. While still early in the earnings season, the results from the bellwethers bode well for others.

column5: Starbucks to Allow Customers to Pay Via Some Smartphones
column8: Starbucks will allow customers at U.S. company-operated stores to use some smartphones to pay for their purchases in an effort to drive sales.

column5: Softbank Sells $660 Million Bonds in Corporate Issuance Flourish
column8: Softbank Corp., the exclusive supplier of the iPhone in Japan, is selling more than $660 million in bonds to institutional investors in another sign that lower-rated companies are returning to the corporate-bond market.

column5: ASML Reports Surge in Profit, Sales
column8: ASML reported record fourth-quarter results, but its shares fell amid concerns over its outlook for the current quarter.

column5: Apple Soars, but Mum on Jobs
column8: Apple posted a 78% surge in profit and record sales of its gadgets in the holiday quarter, but the company's executives ignored the sudden medical leave of CEO Steve Jobs.

column5: Sprint to Raise Smartphone Data Fees
column8: Sprint Nextel plans to add a $10 fee on top of its smartphone data-service plans later this month to offset rising costs from increased wireless traffic on its network.

column5: Two Arrested in iPad Security Breach
column8: Two men were arrested Tuesday in an alleged security breach of AT&T servers last June that may have exposed personal information about 120,000 iPad users.

column5: Low VIX Viewed as an Opportunityï¿½ï¿½For Now
column8: The stock market's volatility index remains near three-year lows, and to some strategists, that is less of a bullish sign than an opportunity to scoop up portfolio insurance before what they see as an inevitable stock-market correction.

column5: Apple Options Traders Ready for Fresh All-Time High
column8: Options traders are aiming for Apple's stock to hit another all-time high this week, a glimmer of optimism not evident in the company's falling share price.

column5: Apple Shares Fall as Jobs Takes Medical Leave
column8: Apple's shares were down less than 3% Tuesday, after falling as much as 6.5% earlier, a day after it disclosed that Steve Jobs would take another unexpected medical leave.

column5: Sony to Close N.J. CD Plant
column8: Sony is closing a CD plant in Pitman, N.J., moving those operations to a factory in Indiana. The change reflects the decline in music CD sales

column5: Baidu Profit Doubles to Quarterly Record
column8: Baidu Inc.'s third-quarter net profit doubled from a year earlier to a record due to increases in users and spending on advertising, as China's top Internet search engine continued to benefit from Google Inc.'s declining presence there.

column5: Nokia's earnings lift stock, new CEO
column8: Nokia shares surged after the company swung to a third-quarter profit, providing a boost for new Chief Executive Stephen Elop and signalling that the battle against its smartphone rivals has begun.

column5: Wal-Mart Set To Sell the Nook
column8: In a move to greatly expand the universe of e-reader customers, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. will begin selling Barnes & Noble Inc.'s Nook device at 2,500 stores and online as soon as Oct. 24.

column5: Kleiner Perkins Plans Social Media Fund
column8: Venture capital group Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers launched a $250 million fund to back entrepreneurs inventing social applications and services, with the backing of Amazon and Facebook.

column5: Apple Updates MacBook Air, Macintosh Software
column8: Apple released two new MacBook Air ultralight laptops that use flash memory for storage instead of hard drives, and promised updated software for its Macintosh computers that borrows features from its iPhone and iPad.

column5: Verizon Wireless to Sell Samsung Tablet for $600
column8: Samsung's Galaxy Tab, one of the first tablets to rival Apple's iPad, will hit Verizon Wireless stores Nov. 11 and cost $599.99.

column5: Silicon Valley 3.0: Tech's New Wave
column8: Silicon Valley's start-up economy has quietly broadened beyond IT to now include a growing cadre of bioscience and "clean technology" firms.

column5: Oracle, Apple: Money Flow Leaders (ORCL, AAPL)
column8: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

column5: Netbook slump tests Acer's record of growth
column8: For two years, Acer has relied on netbooks¡ªtiny, stripped-down laptops¡ªto propel growth. Now the netbook craze is petering out.

column5: Some Flashy Retail Sites Come Up Short on the iPad
column8: Ahead of the holidays, some retailers are fretting that their jazzy websites don't function properly on the iPad because of Apple's refusal to support Adobe Flash technology.

column5: New Nokia CEO Needs Performance of Life
column8: Stage debuts are always big events, and Stephen Elop's will be no different when the new Nokia CEO formally addresses investors for the first time.

column5: Intel to Invest $6 Billion in Plants
column8: Intel said it plans to invest between $6 billion and $8 billion on upgrading its manufacturing technology in U.S. facilities, including building a new plant in Oregon.

column5: Google to Combat India Piracy
column8: Google launched a music service in India to help users search for legal online streams and downloads, a move aimed at combating rampant digital piracy that has held back the country's entertainment industry.

column5: Verizon Wireless to Offer Cheaper Data Plan
column8: Verizon Wireless plans to introduce a $15 data plan with a monthly usage limit for smartphone customers, in a move that follows AT&T's capped offerings.

column5: Drafty Fireplaces Meet Their Match
column8: High-tech fireplace inserts and stoves give options to homeowners with drafty, old hearths.

column5: Options Traders Stick With Apple
column8: Despite disappointment in the stock market over Apple's quarterly earnings, options traders were putting on bets Tuesday that the stock might climb over $320 as soon as Friday.

column5: European Markets Move Lower
column8: European stocks fell, with producers of basic resources pacing the decline following a surprise short-term interest-rate increase by China.

column5: Apple, Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan: Money Flow Leaders (AAPL, POT)
column8: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

column5: Tech Rivals Wage War of Words
column8: Research In Motion said "customers are getting tired of being told what to think by Apple," following Steve Jobs's comments about the BlackBerry maker.

column1: By Leslie Shaffer, Shri Navaratnam, V. Phani Kumar Jan. 18, 2011 5:43 am ET

column5: How Google's Costly Motorola Maneuver May Pay Off
column8: Google suffered some expensive bruises in its two-year foray into making smartphones. But the expense wasn't as big as it appears, and Google may have achieved some strategic ends.

column5: Whirlpool Considers New Trade Case Against Rivals' Appliances
column8: Whirlpool reported earnings growth of 48% and said it is considering a new offensive against foreign-made household appliances it maintains are being sold in the U.S. for less than the cost to manufacturer them.

column5: Verizon Sells $500 Million in Debt
column8: Priced to yield 5.90% with a 40-year maturity, the bonds are aimed primarily at individual investors.

column5: Telenav Acquires Mapping Startup Skobbler for $24 Million
column8: Personal navigation company Telenav has acquired Skobbler, a German startup that makes map apps and mobile games, for $24 million in cash and stock.

column5: How Lenovo Built a Chinese Tech Giant
column8: With its proposed $2.91 billion purchase of Google's unprofitable Motorola handset business, Lenovo is making a risky bet that it can replicate its success in the PC sector with smartphones.

column5: Google Sells Handset Business to Lenovo
column8: Lenovo agreed to buy Google's Motorola Mobility unit for $2.91 billion, a deal that reverses the Internet company's short-lived move into smartphone hardware.

column5: Lenovo-Google Deal Adds to Samsung's Smartphone Worries
column8: Lenovo's purchase of Google's phone business will create a formidable player at a time when fierce smartphone-price competition is already squeezing market leader Samsung.

column5: Motorola Deal to Give Lenovo a 'Shortcut' Into U.S. Market
column8: Lenovo Group Chairman and Chief Executive Yang Yuanqing said the company expects to sell 100 million handsets in the year after it completes its deal to acquire Google's Motorola Mobility unit for $2.91 billion, calling the deal a "shortcut" into the U.S. market.

column5: Amazon to Offer Kindle Checkout System to Physical Retailers
column8: Amazon.com plans to offer brick-and-mortar retailers a checkout system that uses Kindle tablets as soon as this summer.

column5: Qualcomm Posts Higher Revenue
column8: Qualcomm said revenue rose 10% in the first fiscal quarter, countering fears that the chip maker might see a negative surprise from the smartphone market.

column5: Investors Shed Dividend-Paying Stock Funds
column8: As the U.S. Federal Reserve trims its purchases of bonds and expectations of higher interest rates grow, investors are pulling billions of dollars from funds focused on dividend-paying stocks.

column5: Bitter Medicine in Store for Activists
column8: As activist hedge funds step up their hunt for new targets, companies are bolstering their defenses.

column5: Apple Shares Hit Three-Month Lows
column8: Apple shares hit their lowest point in three months after disappointing iPhone sales raised concerns about the company's growth prospects.

column5: In China, the Coolpad Is Hotter Than Apple's iPhone
column8: China is one of the fastest growing smartphone markets and several homegrown brands, such as Oppo and Coolpad, are seeking to challenge Apple and Samsung's duopoly.

column5: J.C. Penney Lowers Threshold for Poison Pill
column8: J.C. Penney lowered the threshold on its shareholder rights plan and extended its expiration date, part of a move to protect its tax benefits.

column5: Apple iPhone Sales, Outlook Come Up Short
column8: Apple reported selling fewer iPhones than projected at year-end and said revenue in the current quarter might decline.

column5: Government Reaches Deal With Tech Firms on Data Requests
column8: The Obama administration agreed to let technology companies make more information public about how often the government monitors Internet use, aiming to ease public distrust and corporate complaints about snooping.

column5: Asian Morning Briefing: U.S. Stocks Retreat
column8: Asian Morning Briefing

column5: Millennial Media's Co-Founder Resigns as CEO, Chairman
column8: Millennial Media said Paul Palmieri¡ªits co-founder, chief executive and chairman¡ªresigned, and the mobile-ad company named former Yahoo executive Michael Barrett as his replacement as CEO.

column5: Ericsson, Samsung Reach Agreement on Global Patent Licenses
column8: Ericsson said it has reached an agreement with Samsung on global patent licenses, ending a series of complaints against each other.

column5: The Return of the Living Dead Products
column8: Now that Sony's Walkman is back, what's next? Joe Queenan has a wish list. Paging the the Nehru Jacket.

column5: Why Retailers Became a Top Target of Patent Trolls
